description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:design_management_design_notification_participants ` feature flag that was added in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/46642.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::knowledge" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_knowledge`
- Best individual to reach out to: @.luke

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

The bugfix https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217095 will be solved and no adverse effects.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

If there is a bug in the feature then the wrong group of people might receive email notifications when the feature flag is enabled.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- Sentry errors

## Beta project

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab design_management_design_notification_participants true`)
- [-] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` by pinging `@sre-oncall`
  - In `#g_delivery` by pinging `@release-managers`
- [-] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set design_management_design_notification_participants true`)
- [ ] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab design_management_design_notification_participants false
```

title: [MR Analytics] Allow filtering for "narrow MR rate"
description:
### Problem to solve

GitLab uses "narrow MR rate" as its primary measure of throughput.  "MR rate" means throughput *divided by author count*, and "narrow" means "limited to MRs authored by members of the organization."  (See [terminology definitions in the handbook](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/merge-request-rate/#terminology).)  The ability to easily display "narrow MR rate" in GitLab itself would be quite valuable to GitLab.  This feature could be generalized to be useful to customers as well.

### Proposal

In MR Analytics, add support for "not" filters.  This will allow filtering for "label != ~"Community contribution"".  This approach will return consistent numbers over time, even as people join and leave the organization.

### Alternative (more complex) proposal

In MR Analytics, add a filter for "access level".  The available options for this filter would be the 4 [Access levels](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/access.rb#L14) starting from "Developer and higher".  Specifying one level automatically includes all higher levels.  The thinking is that Developer+ should all be members of the organization.  The downside is that if someone leaves the organization that would change historical numbers.

title: Support regex-based filtering for SearchFilesByName in the repository model
description:
#### Problem

Our `Repository` model doesn't currently support regex-based filtering to `SearchFilesByName`. We need this to be possible in order to search for all matching paths in a repository. This is needed in order to [support wildcards when specifying include paths in .gitlab-ci.yml](ttps://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/25921).

#### Possible solution: 

```diff
diff --git a/lib/gitlab/git/repository.rb b/lib/gitlab/git/repository.rb
index 1a3409c1f84..d3f45e7a3eb 100644
--- a/lib/gitlab/git/repository.rb
+++ b/lib/gitlab/git/repository.rb
@@ -994,13 +994,13 @@ def can_be_merged?(source_sha, target_branch)
         end
       end
-      def search_files_by_name(query, ref)
+      def search_files_by_name(query, ref, filter_glob = "")
         safe_query = Regexp.escape(query.sub(%r{^/*}, ""))
         ref ||= root_ref
         return [] if empty? || safe_query.blank?
-        gitaly_repository_client.search_files_by_name(ref, safe_query)
+        gitaly_repository_client.search_files_by_name(ref, safe_query, filter_glob)
       end
       def find_commits_by_message(query, ref, path, limit, offset)
diff --git a/lib/gitlab/gitaly_client/repository_service.rb b/lib/gitlab/gitaly_client/repository_service.rb
index 20ad6d0184b..43eaf5bf75d 100644
--- a/lib/gitlab/gitaly_client/repository_service.rb
+++ b/lib/gitlab/gitaly_client/repository_service.rb
@@ -327,8 +327,8 @@ def raw_changes_between(from, to)
         GitalyClient.call(@storage, :repository_service, :get_raw_changes, request, timeout: GitalyClient.fast_timeout)
       end
-      def search_files_by_name(ref, query)
-        request = Gitaly::SearchFilesByNameRequest.new(repository: @gitaly_repo, ref: ref, query: query)
+      def search_files_by_name(ref, query, filter)
+        request = Gitaly::SearchFilesByNameRequest.new(repository: @gitaly_repo, ref: ref, query: query, filter: filter)
         GitalyClient.call(@storage, :repository_service, :search_files_by_name, request, timeout: GitalyClient.fast_timeout).flat_map(&:files)
       end
 ```

#### Related MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/-/merge_requests/2262

title: Dependency Proxy configuration is improperly loading
description:
### Summary The Dependency Proxy feature seems to be enabled automatically without needing to be enabled unlike how it is described [in the documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/packages/dependency_proxy.html). It appears in the Packages and Registries menu in the group screen, can be toggled on and off, and can be accessed via the docker commands and responds as expected. However, even when manually enabled, the `::Gitlab.config.dependency_proxy` configuration lookup returns `"enabled" => false`. Despite being in all other ways functional, the Dependency Proxy does not respond as expected via the API. Specifically, it is not possible to clear the cache via the API as described here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/dependency_proxy.html. ### Steps to reproduce 0. Ensure that `gitlab_rails['dependency_proxy_enabled']` is NOT set to `false` and that Dependency Proxy is enabled in the test group on the web interface. 1. Use the Dependency Proxy as describe here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/dependency_proxy/index.html#use-the-dependency-proxy-for-docker-images. 2. Check the Dependency Proxy page for the test group on the web interface and see that the number of blobs has increased. 3. Attempt to clear the cache using the API. 4. Notice that the number of blobs does not go down. To actually remove the blobs (workaround): 1. Open the gitlab-rails console. 2. Enter `@group = Group.find_by_id(group_id)` where "group_id" is the group_id of the test group. 3. Enter `@group.dependency_proxy_blobs.destroy_all` 4. Confirm that the number of blobs has gone down on the web interface. ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? 1. The Dependency Proxy feature is enabled even if not enabled in the gitlab.rb. 2. The `::Gitlab.config.dependency_proxy` configuration lookup returns `"enabled" => false` even when enabled in the gitlab.rb and gitlab.yml files. 3. Cannot purge the Dependency Proxy cache using the API ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? 1. The Dependency Proxy feature should only be enabled if enabled in the gitlab.rb as described here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/packages/dependency_proxy.html 2. The `::Gitlab.config.dependency_proxy` configuration lookup should return `"enabled" => true` when enabled in the gitlab.rb and gitlab.yml files. 3. Can purge the Dependency Proxy cache using the API ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![dependency_proxy_enable](/uploads/db2addd23f7aa7d2aeff561c4cf304b6/dependency_proxy_enable.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info

title: Add a generic packages tab to the Packages UI
description:
### Release notes 
With the GitLab generic package repository, you can easily publish generic files, like release binaries, in your project‚Äôs Package Registry. Then, install the packages whenever you need to use them as a dependency. However, if you use the Packages UI and another package manager format, you may have noticed that there is no easy way to quickly filter the UI to see only your generic packages. 

Not anymore. We recently added a tab to the Packages UI called `Generic` that you can click on and limit your view to only your generic packages. We hope this helps you to find and validate your packages faster and more efficiently. 

### Problem to solve 
GitLab launched the [generic packages repository](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/generic_packages/) in %"13.6" which allows you to publish and install generic binaries. However, when you navigate to the Packages UI, you can only see these files in the `All` view. This can make it difficult for you to quickly filter only on the generic package type. This problem is exacerbated in projects that use several formats in their registry. 

### Proposal 
Add a tab `Generic` to the Packages UI so that a Developer can navigate to the user interface and quickly find and validate the package they are looking for. 
- Sorting, filtering, and deleting packages should all work the same. 
- Measure UI activity via Snowplow (similar to other formats)

### Testing & Availability

And end to end test is being tracked to cover this package manager.

* General issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249575
* Test case: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/testcases/-/issues/1063

![Screen_Shot_2020-11-05_at_2.19.36_PM](/uploads/7efe449da8e79f6d54a43fd5c79eb324/Screen_Shot_2020-11-05_at_2.19.36_PM.png)

title: Persist alerts
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We would like to store alerts generated by cilium/hubble. Those alerts will be collected by [gitlab agent](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/) and passed to agent-kas server. KAS will then pass information to Gitlab instance trough internal end point.

Network policy alert = is just a alert only difference is that it is coming from K8 trough internal end point

## Relevant links

- Currently relevant issues are gathered under the epic
- More related issues to this one can be found [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3438#note_352161362)

## Implementation plan

- [x] Provide a new endpoint to the [internal api](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/internal_api.html) which will be called by [KAS](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/tree/master/internal/kas)
- [x] Create new service like `AlertManagement::ProcessPrometheusAlertService` to store Alerts. We need to create new service to save Alerts. Currently alerts created from `NotifyService::CreateAlert` and that does additional things our internal end point doesn't need. 
- [x] Add new monitoring tool to module `Gitlab::AlertManagement::Payload::MONITORING_TOOLS` called Cilium
- [x] Add `domain` column to Alerts table
- [x] Add documentation for new internal end point

Note: updating queries to separate views will be covered in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/255751

title: Create a generic security report schema
description:
## Why are we doing this work

Part of delivering the parent Epic's [expected outcome](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4466#expected-outcomes) item 1 is to create a new security report JSON schema as a distribution artefact in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas.

This generic security report schema, henceforth known as the security report schema, facilitates the creation of new security analyzers without requiring a new schema, backend or frontend work. The details are explained in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233168.

## Non-functional requirements

1. [`src/security-report-format.json`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas/-/blob/master/src/security-report-format.json) is still used as a base for all schemata.
1. A new major version of all schemata are released.
1. The resulting schema in [`dist`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas/-/tree/master/dist) matches the implementation in the [PoC MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas/-/merge_requests/45).
1. Given the extra work required to remove the `type` property - which is required to unify schemata - this implementation is not dependent on it. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284063#note_449596263

## Implementation plan

1. [x] Generate a new schema called `dist/security-report-format.json` under the [security-report-schemas](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas) project. This potentially become the "unified" schema at some stage.
1. [x] Update all schemata to have the new `details` field. This can be done by adding it to `src/security-report-format.json`.
1. [x] Bump the patch version of all schemata ([SchemaVer addition](https://github.com/snowplow/iglu/wiki/SchemaVer#addition)).
1. [x] Release new version.

title: Duplicate asset links names are not handled gracefully in release UI and API
description:
### Problem to solve 

If a user tries to create a new release through the **New Release** page and enters two asset links that have the same name, they get a generic error message:

![image](/uploads/5ccb10abd878bc1050947adca22eaad7/image.png)

However, this is **not** validated by the frontend, so it's unclear to the user what went wrong. In contrast, the frontend _does_ validate that the asset link URLs are unique, and disables the **Create release** button if not.

Similarly, if the user is instead creating a release through the API, they get an ugly, technical error message:

```json
{
  message: "PG::UniqueViolation: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint \"index_release_links_on_release_id_and_name\"\nDETAIL: Key (release_id, name)=(2102687, My link title) already exists.\n"
}
```

A similar error message is shown if URLs are duplicate.

### Proposal

We should do three things:

1. Add frontend validation for duplicate link names
1. Update the backend to send a nicer validation message in the case of duplicate link names
1. Same as above, but for duplicate link URLs

title: Epic search in issues inconsistent
description:
## Problem

When searching for an epic in the Epic field of an Issue, the search results are unexpected. See original description or https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/277065#note_442556119 for examples.

## Suggested solution

### Backend

- Implement `searchInput` and `searchFields` in GraphQL queries for listing epics in a group, to allow partial string searches by a defined set of fields

### Frontend

- Update the frontend request to use GraphQL.


## Original description

<details><summary>Summary</summary>

When searching for an epic in the Epic field of an Issue, the search results are unexpected.

</details>


<details><summary>Examples</summary>

### Use-case 1: Searching for Epic "Improve Current Translations"

![image](/uploads/fce06a4fe74909eed1417fbbd3154eb0/image.png)

^^^ I expected that my epic would already show up here, given that it starts with the exact word ‚ÄúImprove‚Äù. However, even if I scroll to the end of the suggested values, my epic is not there.

I also don‚Äôt quite get the ordering of the suggested results. It‚Äôs not alphabetic, but I don‚Äôt know what it is.

![image](/uploads/c07db48e0a2f27316c3914c353ae2461/image.png)

^^^ As I continue typing and type out two full words, no matches are found.

![image](/uploads/1b3362d2482abfc33d06c1bcd70456a8/image.png)

^^^ Starting the last word, still no matches.

![image](/uploads/e23d63a31f4e616bc3e78169b650af3a/image.png)

^^^ One more character and now I finally see my epic.

### Use-case 2: Searching for Epic "Project Export/Import"

![image](/uploads/e1e32144cfdd26aece1af791b09aa6c2/image.png)

^^^ I expect that typing "project export" would find a match.

![image](/uploads/eb5a6ddc4070e88075fff00b93cd4ece/image.png)

^^^ Adding a slash "/" does the trick.

### Use-case 3: Searching for Epic "Github Importer"

![image](/uploads/c5df4ca8d121ce7fe4a09c1104722b9c/image.png)

^^^ No results for "github", even though there should be several.

![image](/uploads/846b712a3b63234aa6eed6994e32d339/image.png)

^^^ Continuing to type, two results appear. There should be more and it feels random that only two are shown. (Why these two?)

![image](/uploads/111235f200e9137f5a9f7023cf3454ea/image.png)

^^^ After typing two full words "github importer", all the epics are found. However, I can't tell the full name of the last choice, as it is cut off. I think that I should be able to see all the choices presented, given that there is a scrollbar inside the search field.

Also, it feels odd that as I type more, more results are found. I would expect the opposite experience - if I type one word, many choices are shown and as I type more, those choices are narrowed. Having the inverse experience is confusing.

</details>

<details><summary>Proposals</summary>

First iteration:
- Implement the `in` parameter in the [`EpicsFinder`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/finders/epics_finder.rb) in the same way as the general [`IssuableFinder`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/finders/issuable_finder.rb);
- Expose the `in` parameter in the [REST API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/epics.html#list-epics-for-a-group); then
- Add `&in=title` to the query on the frontend.

Later:
- Implement `searchInput` and `searchFields` in GraphQL queries for listing epics in a group, to allow partial string searches by a defined set of fields; and
- Update the frontend request to use GraphQL.

</details>

title: Show an alert with a link to the feedback issue to existing CI users when Pipeline Editor is released
description:
## Problem

When we release the new Pipeline Editor, we should promote the new feature and gather feedback from users. 

## Solution

When a user with an existing CI config opens the Pipeline Editor, we should show a one-time, dismissable alert that briefly explains the feature and makes it possible to provide feedback. Once dismissed, the alert won't show up again.

- Feedback issue link https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/298928
- Pipeline Editor documentation https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipeline_editor/
- IMPORTANT: We should show this alert only to those users who have an existing CI config. Those new to GitLab CI/CD will be getting a custom alert as part of the their first time CI/CD experience.

![image](/uploads/9dde33f8e10c88e5c2be747013c430ba/image.png)

For more context on the Pipeline Editor see https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4814

title: Add a confirmation modal warning the user about unsaved changes in Pipeline Editor
description:
## Problem

It's possible to start making changes to your pipeline config in the Pipeline Editor and accidentally close the tab, or forget you made the changes. We should prevent users from losing their changes.

## Proposal

If user has unsaved changes and somehow navigates off the page, we should show a modal that says something like: "The pipeline configuration has unsaved changes. Are you sure you want to close the editor? - Yes, No". 

We should use the small modal component for this. https://design.gitlab.com/components/modal or the system modal if necessary.
